column2: An undulating landscape, with a homely farmstead here and there, and plenty of old English timber scattered grandly over it, extended mistily to my right; on the left the road is overtopped by masses of noble forest.
column3: An undulating landscape, with a homely farmstead here and there, and plenty of old English timber scattered grandly over it, extended mistily to my right; on the left the road is overtopped by masses of noble forest.

column2: The old park of Brandon lies there, more than four miles from end to end.
column3: The old park of Brandon lies there, more than four miles from end to end.

column2: These masses of solemn and discoloured verdure, the faint but splendid lights, and long filmy shadows, the slopes and hollows--my eyes wandered over them all with that strange sense of unreality, and that mingling of sweet and bitter fancy, with which we revisit a scene familiar in very remote and early childhood, and which has haunted a long interval of maturity and absence, like a romantic reverie.
column3: These masses of solemn and discoloured verdure, the faint but splendid lights, and long filmy shadows, the slopes and hollows-my eyes wandered over them all with that strange sense of unreality, and that mingling of sweet and bitter fancy, with which we revisit a scene familiar in very remote and early childhood, and which has haunted a long interval of maturity and absence, like a romantic reverie.

column2: As I looked through the chaise-windows, every moment presented some group, or outline, or homely object, for years forgotten; and now, with a strange surprise how vividly remembered and how affectionately greeted! We drove by the small old house at the left, with its double gable and pretty grass garden, and trim yews and modern lilacs and laburnums, backed by the grand timber of the park.
column3: As I looked through the chaise windows, every moment presented some group, or outline, or homely object, for years forgotten; and now, with a strange surprise how vividly remembered and how affectionately greeted! column2: This general liking for children and instinct of smiling on them is one source of the delightful illusions which make the remembrance of early days so like a dream of Paradise, and give us, at starting, such false notions of our value.
column3: This general liking for children and instinct of smiling on them is one source of the delightful illusions which make the remembrance of early days so like a dream of Paradise, and give us, at starting, such false notions of our value.

column2: There was a little fair-haired child playing on the ground before the steps as I whirled by.
column3: There was a little fair haired child playing on the ground before the steps as I whirled by.

column2: The old rector had long passed away; the shorts, gaiters, and smile--a phantom; and nature, who had gathered in the past, was providing for the future.
column3: The old rector had long passed away; the shorts, gaiters, and smile-a phantom; and nature, who had gathered in the past, was providing for the future.

column2: The pretty mill-road, running up through Redman's Dell, dank and dark with tall romantic trees, was left behind in another moment; and we were now traversing the homely and antique street of the little town, with its queer shops and solid steep-roofed residences.
column3: The pretty mill road, running up through Redman's Dell, dank and dark with tall romantic trees, was left behind in another moment; and we were now traversing the homely and antique street of the little town, with its queer shops and solid steep roofed residences.

column2: Up Church-street I contrived a peep at the old gray tower where the chimes hung; and as we turned the corner a glance at the 'Brandon Arms.' How very small and low that palatial hostelry of my earlier recollections had grown!
column3: Up Church street I contrived a peep at the old gray tower where the chimes hung; and as we turned the corner a glance at the 'Brandon Arms.' How very small and low that palatial hostelry of my earlier recollections had grown!

column2: There were new faces at the door.
column3: There were new faces at the door.

column2: It was only two-and-twenty years ago, and I was then but eleven years old.
column3: It was only two and twenty years ago, and I was then but eleven years old.

column2: A retrospect of a score of years or so, at three-and-thirty, is a much vaster affair than a much longer one at fifty.
column3: A retrospect of a score of years or so, at three and thirty, is a much vaster affair than a much longer one at fifty.

column2: The whole thing seemed like yesterday; and as I write, I open my eyes and start and cry, 'can it be twenty, five-and-twenty, aye, by Jove! five-and-thirty, years since then?' How my days have flown!
column3: The whole thing seemed like yesterday; and as I write, I open my eyes and start and cry, 'can it be twenty, five and twenty, aye, by Jove! five and thirty, years since then?' How my days have flown!

column2: And I think when another such yesterday shall have arrived, where shall I be?
column3: And I think when another such yesterday shall have arrived, where shall I be?

column2: The first ten years of my life were longer than all the rest put together, and I think would continue to be so were my future extended to an ante-Noachian span.
column3: The first ten years of my life were longer than all the rest put together, and I think would continue to be so were my future extended to an ante Noachian span.

column2: It is the first ten that emerge from nothing, and commencing in a point, it is during them that consciousness, memory--all the faculties grow, and the experience of sense is so novel, crowded, and astounding.
column3: It is the first ten that emerge from nothing, and commencing in a point, it is during them that consciousness, memory-all the faculties grow, and the experience of sense is so novel, crowded, and astounding.

column2: My journey was from London.

column2: I could not in the least tell why.

column2: I examined it carefully, and laid it down unopened.

column2: I went through half-a-dozen others, and recurred to it, and puzzled over its exterior again, and again postponed what I fancied would prove a disagreeable discovery; and this happened every now and again, until I had quite exhausted my budget, and then I did open it, and looked straight to the signature.

column2: Mark Wylder,' I exclaimed, a good deal relieved.

column2: Mark Wylder!

column2: There was nothing about him to excite the least uneasiness; on the contrary, I believe he liked me as well as he was capable of liking anybody, and it was now seven years since we had met.
column3: There was nothing about him to excite the least uneasiness; on the contrary, I believe he liked me as well as he was capable of liking anybody, and it was now seven years since we had met.

column2: There was a complicated cousinship among these Brandons, Wylders, and Lakes--inextricable intermarriages, which, five years ago, before I renounced the bar, I had at my fingers' ends, but which had now relapsed into haze.
column3: There was a complicated cousinship among these Brandons, Wylders, and Lakes-inextricable intermarriages, which, five years ago, before I renounced the bar, I had at my fingers' ends, but which had now relapsed into haze.

column2: There must have been some damnable taint in the blood of the common ancestor--a spice of the insane and the diabolical.
column3: There must have been some damnable taint in the blood of the common ancestor-a spice of the insane and the diabolical.

column2: They were an ill-conditioned race--that is to say, every now and then there emerged a miscreant, with a pretty evident vein of madness.
column3: They were an ill conditioned race-that is to say, every now and then there emerged a miscreant, with a pretty evident vein of madness.

column2: There was Sir Jonathan Brandon, for instance, who ran his own nephew through the lungs in a duel fought in a paroxysm of Cencian jealousy; and afterwards shot his coachman dead upon the box through his coach-window, and finally died in Vienna, whither he had absconded, of a pike-thrust received from a sentry in a brawl.
column3: There was Sir Jonathan Brandon, for instance, who ran his own nephew through the lungs in a duel fought in a paroxysm of Cencian jealousy; and afterwards shot his coachman dead upon the box through his coach window, and finally died in Vienna, whither he had absconded, of a pike thrust received from a sentry in a brawl.

column2: The Wylders had not much to boast of, even in contrast with that wicked line.
column3: The Wylders had not much to boast of, even in contrast with that wicked line.

column2: They had produced their madmen and villains, too; and there had been frequent intermarriages--not very often happy.
column3: They had produced their madmen and villains, too; and there had been frequent intermarriages-not very often happy.

column2: There had been many lawsuits, frequent disinheritings, and even worse doings.
column3: There had been many lawsuits, frequent disinheritings, and even worse doings.

column2: So there were Wylders of Brandon, and Brandons of Brandon.
column3: So there were Wylders of Brandon, and Brandons of Brandon.

column2: In one generation, a Wylder ill-using his wife and hating his children, would cut them all off, and send the estate bounding back again to the Brandons.
column3: In one generation, a Wylder ill using his wife and hating his children, would cut them all off, and send the estate bounding back again to the Brandons.

column2: The next generation or two would amuse themselves with a lawsuit, until the old Brandon type reappeared in some bachelor brother or uncle, with a Jezebel on his left hand, and an attorney on his right, and, presto!
column3: The next generation or two would amuse themselves with a lawsuit, until the old Brandon type reappeared in some bachelor brother or uncle, with a Jezebel on his left hand, and an attorney on his right, and, presto!

column2: the estates were back again with the Wylders.

column2: A 'statement of title' is usually a dry affair.
column3: A 'statement of title' is usually a dry affair.

column2: Here is Mark Wylder's letter:--
column3: Here is Mark Wylder's letter:--

column2: 'DEAR CHARLES--Of course you have heard of my good luck, and how kind poor Dickie--from whom I never expected anything--proved at last.
column3: 'DEAR CHARLES-Of course you have heard of my good luck, and how kind poor Dickie-from whom I never expected anything-proved at last.

column2: Do you know anything of him?
column3: Do you know anything of him?

column2: He seems a clever fellow--a bit too clever, perhaps--and was too much master here, I suspect, in poor Dickie's reign.
column3: He seems a clever fellow-a bit too clever, perhaps-and was too much master here, I suspect, in poor Dickie's reign.

column2: Tell me all you can make out about him. It is a long time since I saw you, Charles; I'm grown brown, and great whiskers.
column3: Tell me all you can make out about him. It is a long time since I saw you, Charles; I'm grown brown, and great whiskers.

column2: I met poor Dominick--what an ass that chap is--but he did not know me till I introduced myself, so I must be a good deal changed.
column3: I met poor Dominick-what an ass that chap is-but he did not know me till I introduced myself, so I must be a good deal changed.

column2: Our ship was at Malta when I got the letter.
column3: Our ship was at Malta when I got the letter.

column2: I was sick of the service, and no wonder: a lieutenant--and there likely to stick all my days.
column3: I was sick of the service, and no wonder: a lieutenant-and there likely to stick all my days.

column2: I do not think he is a year older than I, but takes airs because he's a trustee.
column3: I do not think he is a year older than I, but takes airs because he's a trustee.

column2: But I only laugh at trifles that would have riled me once.
column3: But I only laugh at trifles that would have riled me once.

column2: Well, you know he left Brandon with some charges to my Cousin Dorcas.
column3: Well, you know he left Brandon with some charges to my Cousin Dorcas.

column2: Our ship was at Naples when she was there two years ago; and I saw a good deal of her.
column3: Our ship was at Naples when she was there two years ago; and I saw a good deal of her.

column2: Of course it was not to be thought of then; but matters are quite different, you know, now, and the viscount, who is a very sensible fellow in the main, saw it at once.
column3: Of course it was not to be thought of then; but matters are quite different, you know, now, and the viscount, who is a very sensible fellow in the main, saw it at once.

column2: You see, the old brute meant to leave her a life estate; but it does not amount to that, though it won't benefit me, for he settled that when I die it shall go to his right heirs--that will be to my son, if I ever have one.
column3: You see, the old brute meant to leave her a life estate; but it does not amount to that, though it won't benefit me, for he settled that when I die it shall go to his right heirs-that will be to my son, if I ever have one.

column2: So Miss Dorcas must pack, and turn out whenever I die, that is, if I slip my cable first.
column3: So Miss Dorcas must pack, and turn out whenever I die, that is, if I slip my cable first.

column2: She is a wide-awake young lady, and nothing the worse for that: I'm a bit that way myself.
column3: She is a wide awake young lady, and nothing the worse for that: I'm a bit that way myself.

column2: And so very little courtship has sufficed.
column3: And so very little courtship has sufficed.

column2: She is a splendid beauty, and when you see her you'll say any fellow might be proud of such a bride; and so I am.
column3: She is a splendid beauty, and when you see her you'll say any fellow might be proud of such a bride; and so I am.

column2: And now, dear Charlie, you have it all.
column3: And now, dear Charlie, you have it all.

column2: It will take place somewhere about the twenty-fourth of next month; and you must come down by the first, if you can.
column3: It will take place somewhere about the twenty fourth of next month; and you must come down by the first, if you can.

column2: Don't disappoint.
column3: Don't disappoint.

column2: I want you for best man, maybe; and besides, I would like to talk to you about some things they want me to do in the settlements, and you were always a long-headed fellow: so pray don't refuse.
column3: I want you for best man, maybe; and besides, I would like to talk to you about some things they want me to do in the settlements, and you were always a long headed fellow: so pray don't refuse.

column2: 'Dear Charlie, ever most sincerely,
column3: 'Dear Charlie, ever most sincerely,

column2: 'Your old Friend,
column3: 'Your old Friend,

column2: 'MARK WYLDER.
column3: 'MARK WYLDER.

column2: 'P.S.--I stay at the Brandon Arms in the town, until after the marriage; and then you can have a room at the Hall, and capital shooting when we return, which will be in a fortnight after.'
column3: 'p s--I stay at the Brandon Arms in the town, until after the marriage; and then you can have a room at the Hall, and capital shooting when we return, which will be in a fortnight after.'

column2: But he was certainly one of the oldest and most intimate acquaintances I had.
column3: But he was certainly one of the oldest and most intimate acquaintances I had.
